topic.title: HPE Helion Public Cloud CLI Software for Windows PowerShell Compute Examples

body.p: This page provides you some examples of how to use the various commands (sometimes called "cmdlets") for HPE Helion Public Cloud CLI software for Windows PowerShell implementation of Compute.

Note: Use get-help CMDLET -detailed for details about the syntax of each of the cmdlets shown. Just replace CMDLET with the command you want to learn about. For example, to find the syntax for the New-Server cmdlet you could use get-help New-Server -detailed.

section.title: Availability Zone Color Management
section.p: Each availability zone is assigned a color to make it easier for you to recognize which zone you are in. For example, if availability zone 1 is assigned cyan, whenever you are in that zone, all the command-line text is cyan. To see what colors are assigned to each zone, use the get-zones command:
section.codeblock:
PS HPCS:\\> get-zones
Current Availability Zones include
Zone Id Name Shell Foreground Color Is Default ------- ---- ---------------------- ---------- 1 region-a.geo-1 Green False 2 region-b.geo-1 Green True
section.p: To assign a new color to a particular availability zone, use the Set-ZoneColor command.
section.codeblock:
PS HPCS:\\> Set-ZoneColor 1 Cyan
az-1.region-a.geo-1 now assigned to Cyan.
section.p: Use the Zone Id value rather than the zone name to set the color.
Note: The input to the command is case-sensitive; you must use an initial capital letter for the color name. For example, Cyan rather than cyan

section.p: To create a new keypair:
Created keys are stored locally in C:\Users\*username*\Documents\HP directory and in your Public Cloud account by default. A single key-pair can used to create multiple servers.

Note: When you generate a private key, be sure to make a note of the keypair as this is the only time it is displayed. Be sure to store your private keys in a safe location in order to allow ssh connections to that server.
To list keypairs, browse to the KeyPairs directory and perform the ls command:
section.codeblock: PS HPCS:\\> cd Security PS HPCS:\Security> cd KeyPairs PS HPCS:\Security\KeyPairs> ls

Note for Windows Images: A security group requires port 3389 to connect to a Windows instance via the remote desktop protocol (RDP). body.section:
Basic Server Operations
Note: For all of these commands you have to use the server ID, rather than the server name. Your first server will usually have an ID of 0 and then go up chronologically.
To list the currently-available servers:
PS HPCS:\\> cd Servers PS HPCS:\Servers> ls
To create a new server:
PS HPCS:\\> New-Server -n "TestServer" -i "f981eab8-2a2b-53e1-b737-104a9959477a" -f "101" -sg "default" -md "Namevalue1 | value1" -k "KeyName"
Note: Use get-help New-Server -detailed for details about the syntax of the command.
The example command above shows a new server with name TestSever, image identifier f981eab8-2a2b-53e1-b737-104a9959477a, flavor identifier101, security group name default, metadata name-value pair Namevalue1 | value1, and keypair KeyName. This command supports specifying multiple security groups as well as specifying the network to assign to the instance if you have multiple networks. See syntax for more details.
Note for Windows Images: When the Powershell CLI detects you are creating a Windows server, it looks for the keypair .pem file in a specific location. The default location for the .pem file is C:\Users\*username*\Documents\HP. When the new-server operation has completed, the output is the Administrator password to be used with an RDP client. Please make note of it. To reset a password for an existing server:
PS HPCS:\\> Reset-Password -id "0" -p "testpassword08"
Note: This command doesn't physically reset the password on the server itself, just in the CredentialList.xml file in your C:\Users\*username*\Documents\HP directory that stores passwords locally for use in the CLI.
To update the name of an existing server:
PS HPCS:\\> Update-Server -id "0" -n "NewName"
To reboot a server:
PS HPCS:\\> Reboot-Server "0" "SOFT"
Note: A soft reboot signals the operating system to restart, which allows for a graceful shutdown of all processes. A hard reboot is the equivalent of cycling power on the server.
To delete an existing server:
PS HPCS:\\> Remove-Server "0"

section.title: Quick-Connect to an Instance
section.p: To perform a quick-connect to an existing server instance:
Note: In order for the connect-server command to work, your keypair .pem file needs to be in the appropriate location. The default location is C:\Users\*username*\Documents\HP.
This connects you to the server with the ID 0. You can also connect to a server by navigating to a server directory and entering the Connect-Server command with no arguments:
section.codeblock: PS HPCS:\\> cd Servers PS HPCS:\Servers> cd 0 PS HPCS:\Servers\2111> Connect-Server

section.title: Quick-Connect to a Non-Windows Instance
section.p: To connect to a non-Windows instance, such as Linux, follow these steps:

ol.li: Download the latest version of putty.exe and puttygen.exe for Windows.
Make note of the location of your putty.exe and puttygen.exe files downloaded in step 1.
Open puttygen.exe and load the .pem key file used to create the non-windows instance. This file is located at C:\Users\*user_name*\Documents\HP.
Convert the .pem file to the .ppk format by selecting the Save Private Key action.
Save the .ppk file into the same directory as your orginal .pem file and give it the same name.
Launch the SSH session with the Connect-Server cmdlet. Example: connect-server 12345 where 12345 is your instance ID.

section.p: Note: If this is the first time to use connect-server with a non-windows instance, the system will prompt for the location of your putty.exe file. Please provide the fully qualified UNC path. For example: C:\Users\*user_name*\Downloads\putty.exe. This location is stored in your config file located at C:\Users\*user_name*\Documents\HP\CLI.config.
Note: If you use the same keypair name for another instance, you do not need to convert the key from .pem to .ppk again.

section.title: Get-Password
section.p: To retrieve your password for your Windows instance:
Note: This cmdlet is currently available for Windows instances only.
section.codeblock: PS C:\Program Files (x86)\HP\HPCS-Powershell> cd HPCS: PS HPCS:\> Get-Password -s 123456 -k "key_1" Log detected! Administrator Password : [+&/}4CF6EJi
section.p: This retrieves the password for server ID 12345 that was created with keypair name key_1.
Note: The WinCLI looks for the keypair .pem file in a specific location. The default location for the .pem file is C:\Users\*username*\Documents\HP.
To use the Get-Password command, all of the following must be true:

ul.li: The server must appear in the server list
The listing of the EventLog for the server (PS HPCS:\Servers\server_id\EventLog), must display the encrypted key
The server has never rebooted after initial creation.

section.title: Reset-Password
section.p: For Windows Instances only, if you change your Windows password manually via RDP, you need to manually sync the password with the Windows CLI with the Reset-Password cmdlet for the connect-server command to work. If you use the get-password cmdlet to fetch your original de-crypted Administrator password, and it's available, it will overwrite the password sync.
This resets the password for server 1234 to Thisisalongpassword!.
